Award.AwardTitle: Amazon Adventure: A Giant Screen Film, Educational Outreach and Research About 2D, 3D & Dome Formats Using a Gaming Assessment Tool

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
For over two decades NSF has been investing in the development and evaluation of giant screen films for viewing by audiences in science centers and museums. These have been highly successful in terms of audiences reached and project evaluations that indicate their impact on learning. Less well understood is how the unique attributes of giant screen films (e.g., "immersion" and "presence") affect learners in ways that differ from other film formats. This integrated research and media project will contribute to that knowledge base. Project deliverables will include a giant screen film that tells the story of the discovery of biological mimicry (the critical proof for natural selection and in turn, evolution) through the life story of Henry Bates and his travels through the Amazon rainforest more than 150 years ago; 2D dome, and 2D flat format versions; live interactive science demonstrations and educational resources; and workshops for ISE professionals. The film and the related outreach via science centers, social media, and the web are expected to reach large public audiences; workshops and web resources will reach ISE professionals nationally. A strategy for reaching underrepresented audiences through science museums and partnerships with educational societies is a part of the broadening participation effort.

Building on results of an NSF-funded workshop in which researchers, evaluators, and filmmakers began to develop a research agenda to provide evidence about giant screen attributes and their impacts on learning, the research component of this project will focus on the differences in learner knowledge among the various film formats, their unique attributes, and whether format plays a role in science interest and science identity. A baseline study will be conducted to begin gathering evidence on how each of these formats affects learning. Data on audience knowledge gains, interest, and science identity will be collected using a novel tablet-based game-like assessment pre-film viewing, immediately post viewing, and in a later follow-up. These baseline data will inform follow-on research that, over time, can better explain the unique impacts on learning of the giant screen format.

Project partners include the Pacific Science Center, SK Films, Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Rutgers University, and Arizona State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Amazon Adventure project was funded in part by the National Science Foundation. The centerpiece of the project, the Amazon Adventure film, was a 45-minute giant screen film produced by SK Films. The film is based on the true story of Henry Bates' 11-year journey through the Amazon in the 1850's, focusing on his quest as a young man to find evidence of species change. The narrative approach of the documentary film brought to life the amazing "detective" story of Bates who in his quest discovered 8,000 species new to science. The project also included evaluations of the film, educational materials and a research component.

The film premiered at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C. on April 18, 2017. During the grant period, forty-six theaters in the U.S. showed the film, reaching an audience of over 1.3 million people. The film has also been exhibited in ten other countries and translated into seven languages.  The film will continue in active distribution and due to its historical content will not become dated.

 

Informal and formal testing of the film while it was under development informed communication strategies for science concepts dealing with camouflage, mimicry and natural selection. The independent firm, Knight Williams Inc., conducted evaluation of both the immediate and longer-term impacts of the film on science knowledge among general adult audiences. The study was based on viewers at IMAX theaters at Pacific Science Center (Seattle, WA); Museum of Discovery & Science (Fort Lauderdale, FL); Discovery Place (Charlotte, NC); and Museum of Science (Boston, MA). This evaluation demonstrated a dramatic and significant increase in science knowledge by film viewers, including:

                   Viewing Amazon Adventure increased science knowledge.

 Exposure to Amazon Adventure created a substantially meaningful gain in science knowledge such that the average test score of the viewer group exceeded 99% of test scores of the pre-viewer group.

                  Viewing Amazon Adventure modified viewer understanding of personality characteristics of scientists.

                  Nine-tenths interviewed viewers correctly explained that the row of eight butterflies Bates pulled from his collection showed that one species changed or evolved into a new species.

                   Four-fifths interviewed viewers stated that they felt a connection with Henry Bates. 

 

The educational enrichment elements supported by the grant included the development of a live stage presentation kit about camouflage and mimicry for use at informal science education institutions. The kits were designed to be adaptable to a variety of presentations from an informal stage presentation to more intimate discovery cart style interactions with guests. Educational classroom posters and banners about camouflage and mimicry and an interactive computer game about natural selection were also produced. The posters and banners were made available to theaters in the U.S. showing the film. The posters are available online to the broader community at the film's website.

 

The research component of the project focused on studying five different learning formats with fifth graders to explore the differences among the formats in knowledge gain, the acceptance of natural selection, science interest and science identity.  The five formats were a traditional classroom lesson, a small auditorium film presentation, and giant screen film presentations in IMAX 2D, 3D and dome theaters. Both a pencil and paper assessment and an interactive game played on a tablet were used for the study.

 

In the traditional paper and pencil assessment, there did not appear to be any unique results in learning between the formats. But there was a difference in the sense of presence between the classroom lesson and the giant screen formats, which may augment learning.  The data confirmed that the dome format was the most immersive. Interestingly, the research on a tablet-based assessment provided statistically different results among formats.  Language complexity in the paper and pencil assessment may have played a factor as compared with the simpler tablet approach which also used open-ended questions.

 

The tablet results provide a tantalizing area for future study on the value of electronic assessment tools that may be more engaging to students. The caution, however, is that the research questions were not the same in both studies except for the "I want to be a scientist" query.  When comparing the small screen group to the three giant screen formats, it appears that immediately after viewing the movie all groups wanted to be a scientist similarly, but by follow-up those who were in the more immersive giant screen formats increased in their desire to be a scientist. And interestingly, a gender interaction was discovered. It was the girls who drove the increase in the follow-up data in wanting to be a scientist, but only in the larger formats. Thus, screen size may affect boys and girls differently.

 In summary, the project's center piece, the Amazon Adventure film, was well received and will be a life long learning tool for years to come.
